awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Quantum Complexity, Chaos, and Implications for Analog Quantum Simulation
awd_abstract_narration:
Quantum technology is the next frontier in the information revolution that powers the nation's economic engine.  Machines that process information using the microscopic laws of quantum physics can solve critical problems that are intractable with even the most powerful supercomputers, such as design of new high tech materials and pharmaceuticals.  A general purpose quantum computer is still years in the future, but current quantum technology is now sufficiently advanced for private companies and government agencies to pursue the development of special purpose "quantum simulators" that can be applied to select problems. Unfortunately, the operation of such machines can be very sensitive to noise and imperfection, in a manner closely analogous to the "butterfly effect" whereby even the smallest disturbance (metaphorically, the flap of a butterfly's wing) can affect the predictive power of weather forecasts. This project seeks to better understand the tradeoff between a quantum simulator's power to solve hard computational problems, and the extreme fragility of its predictions when subject to noise and imperfections. Such understanding will be essential for the successful application of quantum technology to problems in science and engineering.

Quantum simulation requires access to highly entangled many body systems whose dynamics are complex. It has long been a concern that such systems exhibit "quantum chaos" which will make any large scale quantum simulation hypersensitive to imperfections. Yet, at the same time it is argued that requirements for a special purpose quantum simulation are less stringent than for universal digital quantum computing. This, then, is the tension at the heart of quantum simulation: Can one have the complex dynamics needed to access massively entangled states, and at the same time have a reliable device that is not rendered inoperable by hypersensitivity? In short: Can one trust the output of a non-trivial quantum simulator? The proposed research will put those questions to the test in experiments with a quantum simulator based on the spins of individual cesium atoms. This test bed provides access to state-of-the-art control and diagnostics, and offers the ability to drive and observe a nearly unlimited variety of complex dynamics, including many of the paradigmatic models of analog quantum simulation currently explored elsewhere.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

 Machines that operate according to quantum mechanics can in principle process information in ways far beyond the capabilities of classical computers.  However, their computational power is tempered by sensitivity to noise and imperfections, which disrupts the entangled quantum superposition states on which their computational power depends. A fully programmable, digital quantum computer must therefore incorporate protocols that suppress computational errors, with thresholds for detection and correction that may be out of reach for years to come. Meanwhile, some quantum processors have reached a scale that makes them difficult to model even on the most powerful classical supercomputers. This points towards a class of non-error corrected analog quantum processors that offer a more modest advantage in tasks like optimization, quantum chemistry, and quantum simulation.

Motivated by these observations, this Project had as its main goal to better understand the role played by errors and the limits imposed on analog quantum simulation. The research has relied on a unique quantum processor based on the internal spin states of individual atoms in their electronic ground state. This Small, Highly Accurate Quantum (SHAQ) processor is universally programmable and has the accuracy required to perform very long quantum simulations in a regime of infrequent errors. Key outcomes include

 (1) A novel method for quantum optimal control called "EigenValue-Only" (EVO) control. Playing a role similar to a compiler in a classical computer, it finds an optimal way to map the physics of the system being simulated onto the quantum processor used for the simulation. In our case this yields a nearly 10-fold computational speedup and similar increase in simulation fidelity. While not directly applicable to large scale and/or digital quantum processors, EVO control may be useful in situations where a generic control task involving a small number of qubits is mapped onto a specific piece of quantum hardware such as a quantum repeater. 

 (2) A detailed study to quantify sensitivity to errors in quantum simulation. Most quantum simulations show clear distinction between the fragility of the quantum state, versus the robustness of observable quantities such as magnetization, whose expectation values can be accurately tracked for long times. From this observation, a framework was developed to predict the effect of hardware imperfections on the output of quantum simulators. Notably, we showed that the accuracy with which a physical observable can be simulated depends on the "observable purity", a measure that quantifies whether the possible measurement outcomes are spread out or clustered at certain values. A paradigmatic example of a low purity observable is the collective magnetization of a system of spin-1/2 particles, a popular choice for, e. g., quantum simulations of quantum phase transitions in ultracold gases. 

(3) Large quantum processors are typically quantum circuits built from quantum gates. If so, they must piece together a quantum simulation from small, discrete time steps that alternate between different types of gates, a process of approximation known as "Trotterization". Recent work has shown this can cause instability and chaos in the simulation of quantum systems whose behavior is inherently simple. The appearance of chaos in particular signifies a regime where accurate quantum simulation breaks down. We have studied, in theory and experiment, the interplay between "native" processor errors, Trotterization errors, and the emergence of quantum chaos in quantum simulations. Notably, we found that native and Trotter errors can be balanced against each other, leading to large gains in simulation fidelity. Separately, we have shown that a simplified version of a quantum measure known as an "Out-of-Time-Ordered Correlator (OTOC) offers a robust signature for the presence of quantum chaos. Recently, OTOCs have been of interest in such disparate fields of science as quantum many body systems and Black Holes. Until now, however, their use in the laboratory has been limited because they are difficult to measure accurately.   

BROAD IMPACT
Graduate education has been integral to this Project. It has supported four PhD students, two of whom graduated as PhD's. Both quickly found employment in the quantum sector (NIST and Cold Quanta, respectively). Every student participated in and in most cases presented at annual meetings of SQuInT, a major annual conference held by the US Quantum Information community. Project-related science was featured when hosting undergraduates during a Laboratory Immersion experience offered by the Annual Optics and Photonic Winter School and Workshop, a University of Arizona/College of Optical Sciences outreach event motivating undergraduates to pursue PhDs in optics-related fields.  More broadly, the Project took place within the context of the Center for Quantum Information and Control (CQuIC), an NSF Focused Research Hub for Theoretical Physics that provides a physics perspective on Quantum Information Science. Through weekly group meetings and internal workshops, the research highlighted here has thus impacted a much larger community of students and postdocs within CQuIC, and at partner institutions such as Sandia and Los Alamos National Laboratories.
